intro: Sclerostylis venosa, commonly known as the veined mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the family Loranthaceae. It is characterized by its woody stems and evergreen leaves, which are typically arranged in opposite pairs. The plant derives moisture and nutrients from its host trees, often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Its flowers are small and greenish-white, while its berries are red and fleshy, attracting birds for seed dispersal. Sclerostylis venosa plays a role in ecological interactions, contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
